data.title: atom command from command line should open enclosing folder
data.body:
The ability to do atom [files] from the command line is a really neat trick, however I find the most of the time, I'm inside of the folder already, such as for doing git commands, etc. Why not have the command 'atom' by itself open the folder I'm already inside of, instead either opening whatever last atom windows were left open or a blank file, as is the current functionality?

Example: I'm in ~/Projects/my-git-project inside the terminal. If I run the command 'atom' it should do the same command as if I were in ~/Projects and ran 'atom my-git-project'.

data.title: Auto indent not correct when moving lines up or down
data.body: When you move a group of selected lines up or down, Atom auto indents them to where it thinks they should fit in the code and it is not always correct. It should have the option to disable this flavor of auto indent.

data.title: Babelify the app source too.
data.body: Fixes #10509.

data.title: Column Count differs between tab and space characters
data.body:
Working in a .jade template, the column position can be very important to keep track of. I had an indentation error come back from the compiler, so I had to go through the file line by line in order to compare the position of my line indents.

What I noticed, is that the column count can be different depending on if user uses a tab vs a space.

So for example, 
![screen shot 2016-01-20 at 4 25 59 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12034199/12463615/8839ad20-bf92-11e5-9048-f291c4c788b4.png)

you can see from this that line 9 begins at column 3

however if I backspace the tab character (which is the whitespace char leading line 9) -- and then replace this whitespace char with spaces (spacebar), then column position is 4, not three

![screen shot 2016-01-20 at 4 27 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12034199/12463641/b56ba67c-bf92-11e5-9bee-8af61aa01632.png)

so you can see i did the aforementioned on line 8, deleting tab character and replacing with spacebar spaces... 

col position is 4 under this use case

please address this so that column count is found uniformly, it would make it much easier to troubleshoot 
files where indentation and whitespace affect whether or not code is runnable

data.title: Can't copy a file name from Project Find Results
data.body:
On a find results screen I can select a file name, but If I try to copy it with `ctrl + c` or `ctrl + insert` nothing gets copied into a clip buffer.

**Screenshots and GIFs**
![screenshot_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/150003/12459571/7cdd5f90-bf7d-11e5-9bf3-364244e4f27b.png)

**Atom version:** 1.4.0
**OS and version:** Windows 10

data.title: Atom crashes on startup
data.body:
I've no idea why, but after reboot of my system, when I try to run Atom, it just show me this and nothing more:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3459374/12452868/2daf17da-bf99-11e5-9b75-d7d491eb3f53.png)

I'm working on **Ubuntu GNOME 15.10**. Error:

```
SyntaxError: Unexpected end of input
    at Object.parse (native)
    at FileSystemBlobStore.load (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/file-system-blob-store.js:31:31)
    at Function.load (/opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/file-system-blob-store.js:10:14)
    at window.onload (file:///opt/atom/resources/app.asar/static/index.js:18:39)
```

data.title: Atom launch story is complicated and confusing
data.body:
How to launch Atom in specific states is a bit of magic that is only known to a few. Some features are more obvious like Dev Mode and Safe Mode, but even then the full effects of each of these modes are not fully documented anywhere and therefore they are often misunderstood even by people who use these modes often. The purpose of this Issue initially is to capture the list of initial states that people want to launch Atom into. Eventually we will create a plan and design for making each of them easy, well understood and as obvious as possible to newcomers to Atom. If possible, I'll add links to other Issues, PRs, Discuss topics and other sources to illustrate.
## Atom Launch Modes

These are the modes that Atom more-or-less supports or are implied by the modes that Atom does support.
- Project (whether with single or multiple roots)
- No project — Open specific files with no tree view
- Restore last state (project or no project)
- Restore specific project state
- Dev Mode — Since this is designed as an aid for Atom development, it mostly only makes sense in combination with the project mode (but perhaps I'm overlooking something)
- Safe Mode — Can be combined with any of the above modes (other than Dev Mode)

Each of these should have an obvious and unambiguous way of launching them both from the command line and from the GUI.
### Additional Command Line Thoughts

Sometimes people want to modify the state of Atom from the command line and sometimes they don't. Some consideration should be given to these scenarios:
- Add a file to an open session of Atom
- Add a project root to an open session of Atom
- Launch Atom in any mode when an open session of Atom is running (even when it may seem the user may want one of the two above but doesn't ... for instance "open a file that exists in the project that is open in the current session of Atom, but I want it in a new Atom session with **no** project")
## Mode State

There are things that are serialized and stored when Atom exits. It is completely non-obvious what items belong to this set and what items do not as well as how to restore the saved items when next launching Atom. Decisions should be made about whether some of these items belong to the specific mode that Atom is in or if they are more global state that people expect to be in place the next time Atom is launched (or even an individual file is opened post-launch) no matter what mode Atom is launched in.
- List of open tabs
- Editor state — Where the cursor is in the file, etc
- Unsaved changes to files
- Untitled buffers
- Per file indentation settings
- Per file line ending settings
- Per file encoding settings
- [Pane configuration](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10545)

data.title: Unsaved untitled buffers don't survive an OS crash
data.body:
Unsaved buffers in Atom 1.4.0 (Windows) don't seem to get restored in case of an OS hard reset or equivalent, even though they AFAIK should (ref: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/942). Gracefully quitting the editor doesn't have the same problem.

How to reproduce:
- Have unsaved untitled buffers present and with some content
- Power cycle the computer (hard reset)
- Reopen Atom

data.title: ES6 Files In Core Not Being Transpiled Prior To asar Creation
data.body:
The only reason this works is because `babel-require` is being used. This may have performance implications as more ES6 finds its way into core.

`linter-eslint` breaks on master as a side effect of this, which exposes potential `linter-eslint` or `BufferedNodeProcess` issues: why is `linter-eslint`  or `BufferedNodeProcess` loading `git-repository-async.js` in the first place?

/cc @arcanemagus @thedaniel @joshaber @paulcbetts

data.title: Handle broken submodules
data.body:
Work around https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2/issues/3580.

Otherwise, when we run into one of these phantom submodules we’d:
1. Try to .openExt it.
2. It wouldn’t open the phantom submodule, but instead move up and open the parent repository.
3. Refresh the parent repository thinking it was the submodule.
4. Refresh its submodules.
5. Find the phantom submodule again.
6. Goto (1).

data.title: Opening HTML file causes editor to freeze
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. curl https://www.levycalculators.acc.co.nz/cpx.jsp > cpx.html
2. Open cpx.html in Atom 1.4

Symptoms after these steps:
- The editor freezes after a few seconds: you can't change cursor position, etc. Eventually a dialog box will appear asking if you want to keep waiting or close the window
- You can still use the menu to bring up the open file dialog
- You can resize the window and it repaints correctly

If the file is renamed to have a .txt extension, everything works just fine.
